messages.msgSnippet: I would love to see a picture, actually I would love to talk to you more about it.  My kids are 5 and 3, but we would also like to adopt older children (when
messages.messageBody:
I would love to see a picture, actually I would love to talk to you more
about it. My kids are 5 and 3, but we would also like to adopt older
children (when my kids have gotten older).

What a wonderful blessing...

Bonnie

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] adopting ...
messages.msgSnippet: Hi again Nanci ... WONDERFUL NEWS!!!   *YES*, I d LOVE to see your new dd s picture!!!  (are you serious???  ya know, I m very gullible, lol!!!) ... seriously,
messages.messageBody:
Hi again Nanci ...

WONDERFUL NEWS!!! *YES*, I'd LOVE to see your new dd's picture!!! (are
you serious??? ya know, I'm very gullible, lol!!!) ... seriously, can you
scan her pic??? ohhhhhhh~goodie~goodie :D

ohhhhh, I remember how hard it was to *W~A~I~T* for that *CALL*!!! when our
dcw (dear caseworker) called to say our ds's (now 11) birth mother had
selected OUR FM and he'd be coming home NEW YEARS DAY (born on Christmas), I
immediately ran in the bathroom and THREW UP MY TOE NAILS for HOURS!!! dh
just stood in the doorway and LAUGHED @ ME!!! he said "welllllllllll, I
guess you've got yourself a good case of
MORNING SICKNESS, *M~O~M~M~Y*!!!" (I was sick the entire 9 mths w/ my 2
bio~babies) ... and, you guess it, two yrs later, when our dcw called again
saying "your little son wants to know WHEN he can come HOME!!!"
I handed the phone to dh and RAN FOR THE PORCELAIN THRONE ...

ohhhhhhhh, I know this has been a LONG WEEKEND for you but Monday will be
here before you know it :)
in the meantime nowwwwwwwwww don't forget to ~> *BREATHEEEEEEEEEEEE and
EXHALEEEEEEEEE*!!! ohhhhhhh, I'm excited for you, Nanci ... and I'm sure
everything will work out, fine, just fine <VBG>

Pris

> >WOW, this is GREAT NEWS!!!
> Pris
>
> Yes, and here is an update. I called him this afternoon to make sure that
he had indeed gotten our homestudy. Apparently, he must have gotten it
yesterday, because he had already read it, or at least skimmed it.
>
> He said "I got your homestudy, and it looks good. No, it looks REALLY
good."
>
> He is going to call on Monday, when he has more time, to talk to me some
more about it! Yippee!! (jumping up and down!!!) We are so excited! We
may have our new daughter by the end of the summer! anybody want to see a
picture? :-) Te he...we are kind of giddy, it was so fast on the heels of
that big dissappointment, but it was what we needed in order to not dwell on
the loss of the girls in Oregon, and I am glad that it is happening this
way. Now if only this one goes through all the way!
>
> Nanci K.

messages.subject: RE: [Unschooling-dotcom] adopting ...
messages.msgSnippet: ... Pris Yes, and here is an update.  I called him this afternoon to make sure that he had indeed gotten our homestudy.  Apparently, he must have gotten it
messages.messageBody:
>WOW, this is GREAT NEWS!!!
Pris

Yes, and here is an update. I called him this afternoon to make sure that he had indeed gotten our homestudy. Apparently, he must have gotten it yesterday, because he had already read it, or at least skimmed it.

He said "I got your homestudy, and it looks good. No, it looks REALLY good."

He is going to call on Monday, when he has more time, to talk to me some more about it! Yippee!! (jumping up and down!!!) We are so excited! We may have our new daughter by the end of the summer! anybody want to see a picture? :-) Te he...we are kind of giddy, it was so fast on the heels of that big dissappointment, but it was what we needed in order to not dwell on the loss of the girls in Oregon, and I am glad that it is happening this way. Now if only this one goes through all the way!

Nanci K.

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] adopting ...
messages.msgSnippet: WOW, this is GREAT NEWS!!!  ohhhhhhhhh, just remember THAT CHILD/those CHILDREN is out there; it s just a matter of lots of connecting w/ them, lots of prayer,
messages.messageBody:
WOW, this is GREAT NEWS!!! ohhhhhhhhh, just remember THAT CHILD/those
CHILDREN is out there; it's just a matter of lots of connecting w/ them,
lots of prayer, lots of patience and it'll all fall together when the time
is right; been there done that!!! I wondered if you were
fostering~to~adopt ... man, that program is NOT for the faint of heart, let
me tell you!!! imho, just too many things can happen!!! ohhhhhhhhhhh and
those homestudies are a piece of cake; yeah right!!! I'm sure the
caseworker thinks your fm is wonderful!!! and that's wonderful news about
their agreeing to your h-s'ing, too!!! sounds like you've got a couple of
great advocates on your side in the child welfare system, that's all it
takes!!!

let us know the minute you hear anything and GOOD LUCK!!!
Pris


----- Original Message -----
From: Nanci and Thomas Kuykendall <tn-k4of5@...>
To: <unschooling-dotcom@egroups.com>
Sent: Friday, June 23, 2000 1:02 PM
Subject: RE: [Unschooling-dotcom] adopting ...


> Thank you all for your good wishes regarding the adoption. We are adoptin
straight from foster care and chose not to do foster adopt, as we felt it
would be too disruptive to the children we already have in our home. (ie:
siblings coming in, than possibly leaving, etc)
>
> We had a dissappointment on Wednesday. We heard from Oregon, where we
were preparing for the last four months to adopt a pair of sisters. Our
case went to committee on Wednesday with one other family, and they chose
the other family over us. :-( It is difficult when you have been moving
them into your heart and mind for so long and preparing for them to just let
them go.
>
> But! The good news! The Great Mother provides in her own way. The next
day I found a listing for a little girl (10 yrs) in our very own state
(Idaho) who seems to fit us perfectly. I spoke to her caseworker already
and he is ecstatic about us and wanted us to fax our homestudy "right now!"
He was VERY positive about everything I had to say about our family and
parenting styles (especially Homeschooling, Pris) and he wants this child
placed in a home before the end of the summer. He wants to move on her very
quickly, and I told him that since we were preparing for several months for
the two other girls in Oregon, that the timing would not be a problem for
us. I even asked how she would hadle having younger brothers and he said
her foster mom runs a day care and she is great with the kids!
>
> We are very excited about this child and her caseworker should now have
our homestudy. I am thinking of calling him today to make sure that the
Boise office of our agency got the study to him promptly (really to check
and see if he still thinks so highly of us now that he has it. :-) )
>
> In regards to your question, Pris. I have spoken at length to our worker
about homeschooling and she is very in favor and supportive to us. I have
also spoken at length to the casworkers of kids that we are considered for,
and I always explain why I feel that the IEP and the one on one attention,
the freedom to choose social interactions and groups based on common
interests and on the childs own terms, etc are all very much a benefit for
these children with disruptions in care and hurts in their histories. They
have almost all responded positively. I also wrote an essay for our worker
about Unschooling and our style in particular to help her have a better
understanding so that she could represent us better to the children's case
workers.
>
> I have had run ins with a few ignorant case workers who refused to even
consider us because we homeschool, and that is frustrating, but on the whole
I have not run into that many.
>
>
>
> ------------------------------------------------------------

messages.subject: RE: [Unschooling-dotcom] adopting ...
messages.msgSnippet: Thank you all for your good wishes regarding the adoption.  We are adoptin straight from foster care and chose not to do foster adopt, as we felt it would be
messages.messageBody:
Thank you all for your good wishes regarding the adoption. We are adoptin straight from foster care and chose not to do foster adopt, as we felt it would be too disruptive to the children we already have in our home. (ie: siblings coming in, than possibly leaving, etc)

We had a dissappointment on Wednesday. We heard from Oregon, where we were preparing for the last four months to adopt a pair of sisters. Our case went to committee on Wednesday with one other family, and they chose the other family over us. :-( It is difficult when you have been moving them into your heart and mind for so long and preparing for them to just let them go.

But! The good news! The Great Mother provides in her own way. The next day I found a listing for a little girl (10 yrs) in our very own state (Idaho) who seems to fit us perfectly. I spoke to her caseworker already and he is ecstatic about us and wanted us to fax our homestudy "right now!" He was VERY positive about everything I had to say about our family and parenting styles (especially Homeschooling, Pris) and he wants this child placed in a home before the end of the summer. He wants to move on her very quickly, and I told him that since we were preparing for several months for the two other girls in Oregon, that the timing would not be a problem for us. I even asked how she would hadle having younger brothers and he said her foster mom runs a day care and she is great with the kids!

We are very excited about this child and her caseworker should now have our homestudy. I am thinking of calling him today to make sure that the Boise office of our agency got the study to him promptly (really to check and see if he still thinks so highly of us now that he has it. :-) )

In regards to your question, Pris. I have spoken at length to our worker about homeschooling and she is very in favor and supportive to us. I have also spoken at length to the casworkers of kids that we are considered for, and I always explain why I feel that the IEP and the one on one attention, the freedom to choose social interactions and groups based on common interests and on the childs own terms, etc are all very much a benefit for these children with disruptions in care and hurts in their histories. They have almost all responded positively. I also wrote an essay for our worker about Unschooling and our style in particular to help her have a better understanding so that she could represent us better to the children's case workers.

I have had run ins with a few ignorant case workers who refused to even consider us because we homeschool, and that is frustrating, but on the whole I have not run into that many.



------------------------------------------------------------

Sign up at http://www.idahopagan.com/
